All action basically for survival. All communication simply to keep this ant colony buzzing along in an efficient, polite manner. "Here's your change." "Paper or plastic?' "Credit or debit?" "You want ketchup with that?" I don't want a straw. I want real human moments. I want to see you. I want you to see me. I don't want to give that up. I don't want to be ant, you know?

Description: A sad, innocent kid who instead of receiving a female peer's fond embrace or male friend's extended hand, was given a bayonet, some grenades, and all the lonely bunkers and trenches to waste away childhood idealism. His entire service in the armed forces was the unyielding routine and regiment, destruction and death. The poor, hapless soldier lad, who paraded in violent platoons and infantries, an infant himself, sadly endures mornings that melt into evenings with meal breaks of rum and despair. Then, when we hear of his voluntary, premature death we are quick to castigate hims rather than the horrible invention of mankind, war, that forced him to it.

The agitated poet caught in the cares of life finds refuge in the tranquil ambience of a winter scene. Among dead tree limbs and the dearth of vegetation, the speaker feels one with nature's spoils. Rained down by the ills of existence, the lonely poet finds companionship and belonging in the barren woods. We feel his pain melt away. He soon forgets his strife and becomes engulfed in the merry hum of bee, the feathery snow, the fountain's brink, the fresh, sylvan air, the fringe of summer flowers, the rain that glazed the snow, the massy trunks cased in pure crystal...
Quote: The time has been that these wild solitudes,/Yet beautiful as wild, were trod by me/Oftener than now; and when the ills of life/Had chafed my spirit--when the unsteady pulse/Beat with strange flutterings--I would wander forth/And seek the woods. The sunshine on my path/Was to me as a friend. The swelling hills,/The quiet dells retiring far between,/With gentle invitation to explore/Their windings, were a calm society/That talked with me and soothed me. Then the chant/Of birds, and chime of brooks, and soft caress/Of the fresh sylvan air, made me forget/The thoughts that broke my peace, and I began/To gather simples by the fountain's brink,/And lose myself in day-dreams.

Description: A sensitive dame, heart-bleeding and soul-wrenching, from her arch nemesis, Life. Starved and mocked, emotionally battered and bruised, this unnamed narrator yearns for peace and freedom. With all dreams dissolved, all songs quieted, she cries out with all she ever wanted: a childhood home and playing freely in the sun. Lament after lament, she finally escapes out through a certain door. To her great joy and hope, once crushed to dust in life, she finds her house on a hill, a loving father, songs never to be hushed, and a sun always to be enjoyed.

The friendly, neighborhood hero who wall crawls and swings off buildings on behalf of New York City. Yet underneath the mask and costume is the scientific-minded Peter Parker filled with insecurities and inadequacies. A nerd who never rose stellar on the job or won the girl is nonetheless the witty Spiderman saving the city of goblins and kingpins. Constantly challenged and tested beyond superhuman endurance, shunned at times by a city, losing loves and friends in an entangled web of mutants and crime, Spiderman fights for the little things: a sick girl, a dedicated co-worker, a lost uncle.

America's well-known nerd who stood up for the millions of highly intelligent pupils with social awkwardness. Clad in red suspenders, high-water pants, and thick-rimmed glasses, Steve Urkel has turned the looked down upon geek into a dignified hero. Nonetheless, poor Steve finds himself always stumbling into accidents, mumbling to girls and peers. He suffers frequent ridicules, taunts, and self-inadequacies but his meek, lowly spirit holds a mirror up to human nature, helping to show the narcissistic, egotistic mankind the error of its shallow ways.

Once a determined machine bent on destruction and death, now a learning machine here to serve and protect. From a world of darkness and war, the Terminator must return to a past to save a future. In the gruesome combat against an impossible foe, the Terminator fights to its death, sacrificing himself in the end. Yet he learns along the way the human ways of loyalty, sympathy, and friendship. More than knowledge banks and memory chips in a local mainframe, a soul is present. Who knew robots, machines, could mirror human nature? Who knew a terminator could cherish the value of life?
Quote: The unknown future rolls toward us. I face it, for the first time, with a sense of hope. Because if a machine, a Terminator, can learn the value of human life, maybe we can too.

Description: The rock-skin creature of enormous power and strength yet carries a heart bleeding of self-pity. From a radioactive space accident, the Thing formerly Ben Gordon, a normal looking human being has become a pithy, down-to-earth, monstrous crime-stopper. Among a quartet of superheros, the Thing has found his place. But after the clobberin' time, the galaxy wars, the super villains, he feels ugly and ashamed of his appearance. Even with a blind girlfriend who sees his beautiful, noble soul, the Thing feels inadequate. And when told 'beauty lies within', he nods, sighs, and shrugs his shoulders in silence as he walks away.

The always romantic vagabond who turned life's black and white silent show into a rich, colorful golden symphony. Hard-luck by the stringent economic insecurities of the times, this playful little tramp always makes the most of his poor, downtrodden existence. Always a girl's affections to win and a normal life to muster, the lovable tramp frolics and dances into the hearts of many generations. Ultimately, the tramp reminds us all of the unique beauty, long-lasting and worthwhile, that can be found in the dirtiest of slums, the most ragged of people, and the worst conditions of life.

The suicidal, young ballerina saved at the last minute. Sunken with the despair of all aimless life and unfortunate family, Thereza is paralyzed in body and mind. But a friend, a stranger, a neighbor, lifts her up and recaptures her desire for life. She slowly gains her walking ability and then the grace of her dancing ability. Through it all she pours out a sad gentleness and re-awakened aura born out of friendship and human care. The spotlight and limelight of show business pales to her spirit. The cheers and applause are hushed to the music of her love. So we watch as she twirls, spins, and sways into our rigid, lackluster hearts.

The sweet, lovable young boy wrought in the deprivation of England's poor. Despite being crippled at birth, Tiny Tim has not proven crippled in heart. With a mild temperament infused with a gentle humor and a benevolent spirit, a sparkling gem grew in the dirty, cold repugnance of urban poverty. A crutch at hand, a loving nature in soul, Tiny Tim has been welcomed by all even ruthless and callous men. He has indeed the child essence of God who sought inexpensive joy with his family and reminds all people who made lame beggars walk and blind men see.
Quote: He told me, coming home, that he hoped the people saw him in the church, because he was a cripple, and it might be pleasant to them to remember upon Christmas Day, who made lame beggars walk, and blind men see.

Description: The clean-dressed, eloquent, handsome African American leader of a revolutionary cause who is gunned down by the police on a street on a hot summer day. Part of a Brotherhood to organize a movement and disenfranchised people, Tod Clifton fought hard street corner after street corner until his death. He met his match though on one street corner where Sambo dolls were sold. A policeman with an eager finger put the Harlem youth leader in his place. Tod was an idealistic hope that died young, a hero of a lost cause, a human who died like a dog in a road.
Quote: Think of your own brother or your cousin John. His lips were thick with an upward curve at the corners. He often smiled. He had good eyes and a pair of fair hands, and he had a heart. He thought about things and he felt deeply. I won't call him noble because what's such a word to do with one of us? His name was Clifton, Tod Clifton, and, like any man, he was born of woman to live awhile and fall and die. So that's his tale to the minute. His name was Clifton and for a while he lived among us and aroused a few hopes in the young manhood of man, and we who knew him loved him and he died...His name was Clifton, Tod Clifton, he was unarmed and his death was as senseless as his life was futile. He had struggled for Brotherhood on a hundred street corners and he thought it would make him more human, but he died like any dog in a road.

Description: The agitated, middle-aged man who finds himself alienated and on the brink of total failure. Separated from his wife and sons, distanced from a father, Tommy will refute the poet's line -"no man is an island complete unto himself." From an actor to salesman with odd jobs in between, Tommy holds up a disappointing resume of life. And on a Day of Reckoning, he tries desperately with a cold father and shot at the stock market. Thoughts and emotions crowd in him as New York pounds down on him. In the distance is a funeral that carries a message to the iconic middle-class, frustrated man caught on hard times.

A defiant, hateful runaway slave who eventually becomes one of the bravest heroes of the 54th Massachusetts Regiment during the Civil War. Torn into bits and pieces of rage and revenge due to blatant racism, countless lashes from the whip, and ruthless chases by hounds, Trip epitomizes the dispossessed soldier of the Union army. Yet despite the anguish poverty, the Negro ex-slave becomes a noteworthy fighter and learns the everlasting beauty of family and friends and camaraderie. Though he won himself a grave, Trip won the chance to fight against humanity's cruelest system, slavery.
Quote: I ain't much about no prayin', now. I ain't never had no family, and... killed off my mama. Well, I just... Y'all's the onliest family I got. I love the 54th. Ain't even much a matter what happens tomorrow, 'cause we men, ain't we?

Description: The weary slave who after a long, arduous day finds peace and solace with a banjo and singing family. An old-fashioned man who would gladly exchange heaven's harps with a country banjo. With a wife, children, and gray-haired granny to sing alongside, we see sorrow, daily cares, aches, pains, troubles, disappear into song and laughter. The whole human saga of pain and joy rings in his heart. The black and white world is colored with tunes. Not minding the poor and rough sound, we learn the breadth and purpose of music; the love of family; the powerful testimony of the poor and meek.
Quote: Oh, de music o' de banjo,/Quick an' deb'lish, solemn, slow,/Is de greates' joy an' solace/Dat a weary slave kin know!/So jes' let me hyeah it ringin',/Dough de chune be po' an' rough,/It's a pleasure; an' de pleasures/O' dis life is few enough.

Description: Caught in an overly scrutinized, dystopic London, Winston moves robotically through the eyes of Big Brother and chase of the Thought Police. Any thought veering out of the groupthink, citizens are apprehended and vaporized. But Winston becomes an unknowing rebel who keeps a personal journal and illicit photograph. Slowly he even melts away his robotic nature for a human soul moved by one innocent note long thought to be alien words -"I love you." Of course, the rebel loses, beaten and tortured to death but an inkling of human consciousness remains.
Quote: For some reason Winston suddenly found himself thinking of Mrs Parsons, with her wispy hair and the dust in the creases of her face. Within two years those children would be denouncing her to the Thought Police. Mrs Parsons would be vaporized. Syme would be vaporized. Winston would be vaporized. O'Brien would be vaporized. Parsons, on the other hand, would never be vaporized. The eyeless creature with the quacking voice would never be vaporized. The little beetle-like men who scuttle so nimbly through the labyrinthine corridors of Ministries they, too, would never be vaporized. And the girl with dark hair, the girl from the Fiction Department —she would never be vaporized either. It seemed to him that he knew instinctively who would survive and who would perish: though just what it was that made for survival, it was not easy to say.

Description: The everyman who somehow gets tomorrow's paper today but doesn't use it for personal gain but uses it on a crusade to save lives from children to adults. Mr. Hobson becomes an unpublished hero going out of his way and time for no medals, plaques, bonuses, or applause. He surmounts extraordinary feats to save strangers and acquaintances, old and young, rich and poor, nameless and famous for nothing more than the right thing to do. If any wonder if heroes only come with superpowers, fly in the sky and wear capes, follow Gary Hobson through the streets of Chicago, rolled up sleeves, sneakers, jeans and paper in hand on yet another mission to save the day as a regular guy
Quote: Sometimes that's all a hero is, Chuck - the guy who's there.

Description: A washed up boxer weary of the world, seen enough dashed dreams and hopes to no longer believe in magic and sees the world as hard and cold as a concrete sidewalk. Bruised and beaten, pounded and pummeled, through the anguish years, Bolie Jackson wears the scars of his soul out in the open. But a little boy comes to teach him about wishes, about magic, about believing. And then an episodic moment between flash of stadium lights, the piercing shouts of crowds, the knockout fists of sluggers, Bolie somehow begins to believe. And no longer is a concrete world a lasting thing. And the true prize of a prizefighter isn't weighed in gold but believing in ideals higher than gold and glory.
Quote: Little boys. Little boys with their heads full up with dreams. When do they find out, Frances? When do they suddenly find out that there ain't any magic? When does somebody push their face down on the sidewalk and say to them, 'Hey, little boy, it's concrete. That's what the world is made out of, concrete.' When do they find out that you can wish your life away?

Description: The New York City hobo who squats in rich homes during drifting seasons, Alyosius T. McKeever goes on merry adventures with a trusted sidekick. And one unlikely winter he finds a family among strangers, among the impoverished and unemployed, left-outs and left-behinds or so he thinks. But through the days, the missions, the meals, the songs, the laughter, Alyosius helps to show us what makes a home, meaning of true love, the festive Christmas spirit, the truly rich man. All in all, his weary wanderings from cityscapes to countrysides and back, we learn the worst poverty isn't the rags, eating out of garbage cans, being homeless but doing so alone without friends.
Quote: Tomorrow we must put the house in order so that everything will be just as we found it. Tonight is our last night together. Our paths may never cross again. And I would like to feel that you're all my friends. For to be without friends is a serious form of poverty.

Description: Gun-toting hired gun amid the Western badlands, Chris Adams saves a tiny, poor farming village from ravenous, bullying locusts. With help of six others, Chris leads a defensive charge for more than the money but for an honor, a law higher than courts. But still Chris is a wanderer. He fights the enemy, seeing the bullets, the blood and bone, then continues on like the wind. No warm home waits for him. No family is his. Just bartenders, faro dealers, rented rooms, hash houses, dusty streets, and weary horizons. So even the sharpest shooter, the tough guy who surmounts any odd, beats every enemy, wins every death-defying challenge can still lose.
Quote: Only the farmers have won. They remain forever. They are like the land itself. You helped rid them of Calvera the way a strong wind helps rid them of locusts. You are like the wind, blowing across the land and... passing on. Vaya con Dios...The old man was right. Only the farmers won. We lost. We always lose.

Description: The unlikely crusader of the common man, Long John Willoughby becomes an overnight hero. From a pledge to commit suicide on Christmas Eve because of the ills of the modern times, Long John gained attention somehow of the media, powerbroker elites, and politicans. Like the first John Doe, Long John beings a campaign of hope and fellowship to rejuvenate the human spirit, to look out for neighbors, the ill and unemployed. And his people's movement ushers in the crowds and stadium applause among radio waves. But then the dream is shattered by riots, confusion, and iron hand of grim reality. But for a moment, Long John made a perfect pitch and the nameless, faceless little guy, the John Doe, became a hero.
Quote: Yes, sir, we're a great family, the John Does. We are the meek who are -- who are supposed to inherit the earth. You'll find us everywhere. We raise the crops; we dig the mines, work the factories, keep the books, fly the planes and drive the busses. And when a cop yells: 'Stand back there, you!' He means us, the John Does! We have existed since time began. We built the pyramids. We saw Christ crucified, pulled the oars for Roman emperors, sailed the boats for Columbus, retreated from Moscow with Napoleon and froze with Washington at Valley Forge...if each and every John Doe would make that spirit last 365 days out of the year, we'd develop such strength, we'd create such a tidal wave of good will that no human force could stand against it. Yes sir, my friends, the meek can only inherit the earth when the John Doe's start lovin' their neighbors. You better start right now. Don't wait till the game is called on account of darkness. Wake up, John Doe. You're the hope of the world.

Description: The daughter in a post-war, fading aristocratic family who struggles materially and socially. A tortured soldier suicidal for a brother; a sick, dying, hapless woman for a mother; an anguished alcoholic author for a lover, Kazuko bears a heavy load as a Japanese young woman in a changing world. She writes soul-wrenching letters waiting and waiting for an outlet, a chance, a hope. We feel the heart-engulfing experience of industrializing modernity transitioning into a new period. Kazuko embraces such a change in family, in love, in herself toward an unknown future. We know now a falling aristocrat can still be a heroine and heaven waits to answer her soul-wrenching letters to the meek.
Quote: To wait. In our lives we know joy, anger, sorrow, and a hundred other emotions, but these emotions all together occupy a bare one percent of our time. The remaining ninety-nine percent is just living in waiting. I wait in momentary expectation, feeling as though my breasts are being crushed, for the sound in the corridor of the footsteps of happiness. Empty. Oh, life is too painful, the reality that confirms the universal belief that it is best not to be born.

Description: The unknown hidden talent born and raised in a dusty Pennsylvania coal mining town. Olga fights her way into Hollywood show business, appreciating any luck along the way. With a twinkle spark in a star, a spirit of song and smiles, Olga never forgot where she came from. Playing the role of a revolutionary, godly crusader, Olga herself becomes a crusader for the meek: the tired brood of her people in a dusty coal town. The kind, beautiful unknown actress even gives her life for an ideal beyond herself. And when death seems to close the door, bury her story and talent in a vault, Olga's spirit lives on to create miracles. Rest in peace, Olga, among the meek in that promised land where all stories are told and never forgotten.
Quote: I hope it's true. Because I didn't play Joan alone. A lot of people played her, people you never seen or heard: my dad, and all the other poor, sad people of Coaltown...I want you to know it and remember why I did it, why I kept on...it's because of all those poor people, all those people I came from who have hopes and dreams in them and never get a chance. They just work and die and all the nice things inside them never come out. And Bill, I came out of them. When they hear me, they'll know it's their own hearts speaking. When they see my name shining in all the theaters, it will be something of theirs shining. Oh, Bill, I'm very happy. I did my job.

Description: The small town New York musician who battles hopelessness and purposelessness. Joey Crown only has a beloved trumpet and a bottle to get through the days. Broke and broken, an aimless alcoholic nobody without a girlfriend, prospects, rotting away in a crummy one-roomer with dirty walls and cracked pipes. Little wonder he can pour out his soul in a brass instrument and make audiences cry. Sure Joey had enough and stepped off a curb but a second chance gave him purpose and direction again, an empty life filled with space and volume. Even in his catharsis we believe the hard luck among us can catch a break, win in the end even if that end is when Gabriel blows his horn.
Quote: Because I'm sad. Because I'm nothing. Because I'll live and die in a crummy one-roomer with dirty walls and cracked pipes and I don't even have a girl. I'm going to be a nobody whose half of me is this horn. I can't even talk to people, Baron, because this horn -- that's half my language. But when I'm drunk, Baron...oh, when I'm drunk, boy...I don't see the dirty walls or the cracked pipes. I don't know the clock's going, that the hours are going by. 'Cause then I'm Gabriel. I'm...I'm Gabriel with the golden horn. And when I put it to my lips, it comes out jeweled. Comes out a symphony. Comes out the smell of...fresh flowers in summer. Comes out beauty. Beauty. When I'm drunk, Baron. Only when I'm drunk.

Description: An expert-trained martial artist with a soft, inner core. Betrayed by family, abandoned by friends, daily attacked in a prison, Sun endures with a gentle, fighting spirit. She helps impossible odds around the world and surmounts the evils, the bullies, the snakes. Even on a hard-bent focus for revenge, friends in spirit help her see the way. A revolutionary at heart, a romantic deep within, we no longer question if a fist, a jab, a hook, a kick is a harder blow than the heart and mind. With Sun Bak on the frontlines, there indeed is nothing more mightier than the meek. And fighting for the nameless and faceless, the meek together can inherit the earth

Anyone who wonders if superheros are frail, that courage with superpowers is fragile, that fear incarnate can shape a soul, look no further than Morph. The jokester shapeshifter was a crucial member of a team. Then in a heartbeat became an abandoned, throwaway character. And since then Morph fought his way back from nightmares of sentinels all alone. Yes, his confidence is shaky. Yes, in crucial moments of combat, he froze. And yes, he may never trust his mental fortitude completely. But no, this estranged X-Men is not a loser. He won the hearts and minds of any human or mutant who beat hard odds, stayed true to themselves, stared Fear itself in the face and survived.

Only a metaphor for a larger theme but the hopeless character comes to life in the opening stanza. For we all could see the mariner, the weary, stranded, drifting lost soul in the depths of a wide sea. We all pushed on in the dark, all alone, hoping to find that harbor of friendship and love. The unnamed mariner embodies the numbed anguish of loneliness, the despondent desire for something else. His ship-wrecked woe, his brooding tortured soul, his fateful demise encompasses the tragic human condition of the meek. Mute and longing, he drowns in the darkness but still hopes while sinking into the limitless deep -a fire that no water could put out.
Quote: He is ever drifted on/ O'er the unreposing wave/To the haven of the grave./What, if there no friends will greet;/What, if there no heart will meet/His with love's impatient beat;/Wander wheresoe'er he may,/Can he dream before that day/To find refuge from distress/In friendship's smile, in love's caress?

Description: The English-Scotsman who tried everything to prove himself a good man. As a monk, in the army, running a race around the world, pushing a button every 108 minutes for 3 long years in an underground vault on a mysterious island, Desmond tried and tried. And in his trials and tribulations, in all his sincerity, he did win the love of a faithful, loyal woman. But still lost in time and space, enduring dangers and risks, Desmond keeps on trying to reunite a lost heart with a found one. Aye, we all were once penniless and broken, fighting to prove our worth with only love to keep us going. So Desmond's story is one of the commoner's, and makes him indeed our brother.

The warehouse city worker who sits at his desk and keeps a long, abstracted gaze outside the window, day in and day out. So calm, so steadfast, tinged with quiet, accepting sadness even captures the wonderment of neighbors across the street. Amidst the din and chaos of daily hustle and bustle, the many thousand/million peopled traffic, all the sights and sounds, the nameless warehouse worker never flinches or waivers, stirs or moves. Nothing of interest catches his eye. No angry or joyous thought changes his expression. He just sits and states in somber brooding. His epic silence and mysterious looks seems to imbibe all the throe and woe of the human condition, of human thought and feeling, and does so loud and clear.
Quote: 'Child, child', it said, 'have patience and belief, for life is many days, and each present hour will pass away...we who have stormed the ramparts of the furious earth and been hurled back, we who have been maddened by the unknowable and bitter mystery of love, we who have hungered after fame and savoured all of life, the tumult, pain, and frenzy, and now sit quietly by our windows watching all that henceforth never more shall touch us...We have outlived the shift and glitter of so many fashions, we have seen so many things that come and go, so many words forgotten, so many flames that flared and were destroyed; yet we know now we are strangers whose footfalls have not left a print upon the endless streets of life. We shall not go into the dark again, nor suffer madness, nor admit despair: we have built a wall about us now. We shall not strike against the wall at night and cry no more! We shall not hear the docks of time strike out on foreign air, nor wake at morning in some alien land to think of home: our wandering is over, and our hunger fed. O brother, son, and comrade, because we have lived so long and seen so much, we are content to make our own a few things now, letting millions pass.'

Description: The young hombre who find himself a misfit for being born. A nerd, overweight kid from New Jersey who never had a chance and wanted what all raging, hormonal Western boy wants: action-packed comics; imaginative thrilling sci-fi fantasy; the soft, tender touch of a female peer; the cool respect of male cliques. Oscar got a little of the former, but not much of the latter. The second-generation Dominican tries to go on somehow through the high school, college, career years. But with family curses above, a tragic island story behind, suicidal attempts over a bridge, a minority enclave all around, friends, sister, mother could not save the hard-luck kid. The frustrated Oscar dies for that little bit of normalcy, the touch and taste, all the regular world knows but not his meek kind.
Quote: So this is what everybody's always talking about! Diablo! If only I'd known. The beauty! The beauty!

Description: The recent university-educated preacher who joins the Welsh coal mining town with a heart and spirit ready to lead a chapel and community. Along the way, he mentors a child with an unfortunate accident, ordains a wedding and funeral, guides a weary, bitter flock, and falls in love. But Mr. Gruffyd keeps his heart in his work and God, denying his human side. And yet unfortunately, the inspired, young preacher meets the hard, superstitious, fearful, black ignorance of religious zealots who knows all the laws but not the love. Eventually, a now broke-hearted, weary preacher, Mr. Gruffyd must leave giving up the Alexander-charged army for golden truth. But for a time, Mr. Gruffydd was part of the last greenery before the black coal dust descended on the village
Quote: Huw, I thought when I was a young man that I would conquer the world with truth. I thought I would lead an army greater than Alexander ever dreamed of, not to conquer nations, but to liberate mankind. With truth. With the golden sound of the Word. But only a few of them heard. Only a few of you understood. The rest of you put on black and sat in Chapel. Why do you come here? Why do you dress your hypocrisy in black and parade before your God on Sunday? From love? No. For you have shown that your hearts are too withered to receive the love of your Divine Father. I know why you have come - I have seen it in your faces Sunday after Sunday as I've stood here before you. Fear has brought you here. Horrible, superstitious fear. Fear of divine retribution - a bolt of fire from the skies. The vengeance of the Lord and the justice of God. But you have forgotten the love of Jesus. You disregard His sacrifice.

Description: The jaded club owner in a foreign country caught up in war-torn times, desperate people, and crime infestation in every corner, Rick Blaine is a weary expatriate with a broken heart. And even as time goes by, he wants to mind his own business and let the world war rage on. But then an old love stirs his dead embers of a heart, reminding him of love-filled times in Paris that ended in a rainy moment at a train station. Yet color, light, even purpose begins filling in him. He finds closure to his heartbreak and now aims to save lives across continents, siding with the Allies. Rick no longer dwells in the past but keeps it as a token and treasure even if little peoples' lives don't amount to a hill of beans in a crazy world.

Character: Singer, I Ain't Got No Home
Description: The hard-luck John Doe, dispossessed and disenfranchised, struggling to make ends meet in a sea-widening world of rich and poor. A wandering worker trying to find the breadcrumbs of livelihood; a farmer with paltry returns on yields, the singer is a weary, lone soul who loses the little he had from the storms of the economy. And the police, a banker, the rich man make the road a little bit longer and the load a little bit harder. Then the narrator tells of brothers and sisters trying their luck elsewhere to no avail, and a poor wife who passes away. Our luckless, hapless hero, poor little guy, show us the savage jungle our garden Earth can be with its peopled systems and that life is hard and then you die.
Quote: I ain't got no home, I'm just a-roamin' 'round,/ Just a wandrin' worker, I go from town to town./ And the police make it hard wherever I may go/ And I ain't got no home in this world anymore./ Was a-farmin' on the shares, and always I was poor;/ My crops I lay into the banker's store./ My wife took down and died upon the cabin floor,/ And I ain't got no home in this world anymore./ ...Now as I look around, it's mighty plain to see/ This world is such a great and a funny place to be;/ Oh, the gamblin' man is rich an' the workin' man is poor,/ And I ain't got no home in this world anymore.

Description: The musician who plays for the derelicts and strays, the hopeless and mundane of the world, the lost and lonely on a Saturday night. The piano man comes to be the only color to their dull lives, reminding the old of a lost youth, the failures of old ambitions, the lonesomeness of a small company. And in his rhythmic crooning and piano strokes, the piano man himself is part of the meek bar crowd. He too knows and feels and sings away abandoned hours, heartsick blues, life ever after for the has-beens and left-outs. Who knew music could bring together a hard-luck people? Indeed if ever misery loves company, for a span in time and space it did so with the power of music.
Quote: Now Paul is a real estate novelist/ Who never had time for a wife/ And he's talkin' with Davy, who's still in the Navy/ And probably will be for life/ And the waitress is practicing politics/ As the businessmen slowly get stoned/ Yes, they're sharing a drink they call loneliness/ But it's better than drinkin' alone/ Sing us a song you're the piano man/ Sing us a song tonight/ Well we're all in the mood for a melody/ And you got us feeling alright

Description: The cleaner who was a faithful, dutiful servant with one goal held firmly to the end. And when a fork in the road made it time to choose, Mr. Kaplan held resolute in her convictions. A sweet, endearing nanny to a child she held on as a quiet protector. But for her firm oath, Kate was gunned down and left for dead in an empty field. Poor Mr. Kaplan who cleaned up so many dead bodies nearly became one herself all because she obeyed an old promise that required disobeying a new one. Mr. Kaplan stayed on in the shadows of a criminal empire: sacrificing, denying herself, losing loved ones along the way. And at another fork in the road, Mr. Kaplan leaped into the abyss, ending the endless questions of good or evil, friend or foe, hero or villain?

Character: Old Man in Dark in the Forest, Strange As Time
Description: The genial spirit who spent his last hours on a train in Germany conversing with a stranger. Warm-spirited, heavy-accented the dying old man exchanges politely and passionately in a human moment. Seeking health, departing from a loved one, curiously questioning of the who-where-when, the elderly man is a mysterious interesting fellow. But we see his world-weariness, all the long miles trekked in his soul. He sits in contrast to the hot-tempered, blood-roaring, excited young man he talks with on the train. Where his conversational companion hungers for all the rivers, hills, fields, towns, cities, peoples, the old man wants just one: one life, one time, one place. After passing quietly away, he teaches us that in all of life a little is enough.
Quote: You are very young. Yes. Now, you vant to see it all and to haf it all -but you haf nothing. Zat is right -Yes? Zat vill all change. Some day you vill vant only a little -maybe, then, you haf a little. And dat iss better -Yes? I know. I know. Myself, I had gone everyvere like you. I haf tried to see everyt'ing -and I haf had nothing. Now I go no more. Everyvere it iss de the same. Fields, hills, mountains, rifers, cities, peoples -You vish to know about zem all. One field, one hill, rifer...zat iss enough!...One life, one place, one time.

Description: The lost, blind wretch who found his way because of grace alone. He has witnessed a catharsis of heavenly proportion; an inspiration of unreal breadth and depth; an awakening that transforms a soul. We too partake in the wholesome change. Forever now humble and earnest, good and kind, the singer accepts and understands it all. He has let faith seep into his pores and now is kept from snares and dangers to come as he is lead home. He embraces a loving Lord. He sees without the eyes. He sings beyond the words. Northing of this world can break his faith now as he surmounts any hard odds. Now with shield he goes on, meek and pure, teaching us meekness is more than a state of being but mind and spirit.
Quote: Amazing grace! How sweet the sound/ That saved a wretch like me!/ I once was lost, but now am found;/ Was blind, but now I see./ 'Twas grace that taught my heart to fear,/ And grace my fears relieved;/ How precious did that grace appear/ The hour I first believed.

Description: The dying mother finally relieved of her heartache life. She tells her son on a deathbed of her long-sought freedom in passionate eloquence. Too hard she endured a cursed, rebuked, and scorned life. She raised a son, struggling in a family after a father died. Now she exclaims: “”I'm going home.”” Her love no doubt will live on as she happily ends her earthly appointment. We feel her pain subsides, her tears forever wiped away, her trials and tribulations a remote past, her troubles over. Any infirm, sick, dying, aged can welcome her story. Any healthy, vibrant, hopeful, young can understand her relief. And all meek souls here and after can know a sweet relief will come; and a carnal world will not imprison for long beautiful souls.
Quote: I've been cursed, I've been scorned/ I've been talked about sure as you're born./ I've seen men kicked around/ With their head down to the ground/ But I'm free at last./ ...I have lived my life down here/ Having her child down through the years/ But I got to leave you alone/ But you got to be real strong and carry on/ But I'm free at last...Son, don't know I'm free. Don't worry about me, I'm going home...I'm going where the wicked will keep from trouble is...Going home. Yes I am...Going where the weary got to be at rest…

Description: A soldier to the very end, John Reese transformed from a purposeless vagabond to the man in the suit who saves lives with mission calls from an AI entity. Expert-trained special forces operative John endured the blackest of high-order secretive crimes. And years later he becomes a lost soul: no home or family, no spouse or friend, no job to return to, no peace within from raging war lands. He did though find his calling in protecting the helpless and innocent on a subway train. From there the man in the suit goes on to fight for more nameless out there under the surveillance of a machine. And at the crossroads, John protects to the very end, giving his life for the cause and raises the 21st century question: can a machine have a soul like a human?

The little guy who is the level-head in a dysfunctional family, Bud is laughed at and teased for his romantic mistrials. He always tries hard to impress a girl he can never win. But Bud stands tall and mighty for all the other little guys out there, all the misfits who live in one-roomers and basements but tries hard in school, at work, in public spaces. College-bound Bud makes it out on his own despite the setbacks, the letdowns, the bullies, the insults and injuries. His tragic situations even carry comedic undertones but America sees a cast-out boy trying hard to prove himself a man even long after he already claimed the title. No one who knows Bud's hard-luck story can claim size makes a man.

The hard-luck kid from the other side of the tracks. Never grew up in a stable, two-parent, middle class home like his long-time buddy, Shawn Hunter is a survivor. Good with the ladies, fights off the bullies, average in the grades, Shawn is the leather-jacket, slick-talking, seat-slouching higher schooler with a good heart. We see Shawn growing up from a junior high kid to a collage young man torn between the bad boy image to the faithful nice guy. But the road was tough with absent father, troubled mother, long-lost brother, always proving something to the world and himself, and always fighting off peer pressure and emotional bullies. And so without surprise the restless kid laments on the big stage at graduation time, “”I could have done better.””

Once a childhood troublemaker and partner to a budding hoodlum, then turned to a priest fighting the impossible fight against a corrupt city racket for the sake of neighborhood kids. Father Connolly tried it all to save slum kids from crime with recreation sports to a church choir. But his own childhood friend discourages the process but might be the only saving, redeeming grace to help the cause. Torn between the gray continuum of morality, friendship, duty, Father Connolly held firm to his heavenly convictions. He mustered the courage born in heaven to save lost youth who worshiped the wrong kid of heroes. And he learned to beat the power machine and hoodlums one must become an angel with a dirty face.

The angelic voice that knows all too well earthly trials and tribulations. And no matter what road her companion treads or what load they bear, the speaker promises to walk alongside her friend. With an unconditional love to endure the nights and even face death itself, the voice rings a chorus and refrain strong and true. She promises with ceaseless affirmations to the longest mile, through grayest day. No more suffering in loneliness, in heartache, in misfortune, misery or suffering. And from the bottom pits of that woe, our heroine welcomes the magic of human companionship. And if we listeners ever doubt the voice that no one will truly walk with us in our darkest times, we are yet reminded over and over again by the singer: “”Yes I will.””
Quote: When you walk down the road/ Heavy burden, heavy load/ I will rise and I will walk with you/ When you walk through the night/ And you feel like you want to just give up, give up, give up on the fight/ I will come and I will walk with you/ Walk with you/ Until the sun don't even shine/ Walk with you/ I'll be there all the time/ I tell you I'll walk with you/ See you through/ When you walk from this place/ And you gotta go to meet Him face to face/ Take my hand and I will walk with you

Description: He wakes in the morning and asks the life and death question. The hard-luck young black man whose life has been cut across by the concrete divide of inequality. Frustrated, confused, soul exasperated the singer pours out rhymes to make sense of a senseless existence. Poverty walls him around. Police barricades his life outcomes. Prisons are a certain future. And still he sings about potential changes with no strangers, drug dealers, gang bangers; no systematic hate, racism, or evil, only heaven healing and the simple times of childhood. And we only hope things can change and weary souls can lean back at ease. But we know too our hero will be another statistic striving to change the world and die trying.
Quote: And still I see no changes can't a brother get a little peace/ It's war on the streets and the war in the Middle East/ Instead of war on poverty they got a war on drugs/ So the police can bother me/ And I ain't never did a crime I ain't have to do/...And I never get to lay back/ 'Cause I always got to worry 'bout the pay backs/ Some buck that I roughed up way back/ Comin' back after all these years/ Rat-a-tat-tat-tat-tat that's the way it is uhh

Description: Finally, he rests at ease. Finally, the thirst is quenched, the moaning and groaning, the sighing and sobbing are over. We even feel the relief in our own limbs from his words. Where some people lead content lives, all hungers assuaged, all loved ones near, this speaker had it hard, bore a load of the soul. Death gave him a cure to the sickness. And though the living dread the state of passing away, the speaker welcomes it deeply and joyously, pillowing his fevered, maddened head on the heavenly breast of a long, lost love. Oh what a sweet, composed, delicious sleep our anguished friend enjoys now near the sound of tranquil waters with only love as his eternal essence.
Quote: Thank Heaven! the crisis,/ The danger, is past,/ And the lingering illness/ Is over at last—/ And the fever called "Living"/ Is conquered at last./ ...The moaning and groaning,/ The sighing and sobbing,/ Are quieted now,/ With that horrible throbbing/ At heart:—ah, that horrible,/ Horrible throbbing!/ ...The sickness—the nausea—/ The pitiless pain—/ Have ceased, with the fever/ That maddened my brain—/ With the fever called "Living"/ That burned in my brain./ And oh! of all tortures/ That torture the worst/ Has abated—the terrible/ Torture of thirst/ For the naphthaline river/ Of Passion accurst:—/ I have drank of a water/ That quenches all thirst:—

Description: The lovable alien from a sister planet who joins a teenage superhero team to fight for justice. But Miss Martian with unbelievable power of telekinesis, flight, shape and density shifting is a torn, meek soul. She grew up in a lonely childhood with an old-time TV series to give her inspiration. And she bears the scars of an oppressed minority white Martian at odds with green Martians. Even too she bears the burden of keeping her hideous, true form from the world and her friends. Yet Miss Martian soon learns love conquers all and friendship, romance, family, heroism are the real powers one can have where all else pales in comparison.

Barricaded in his dark home in a provincial-minded Alabama town, Boo Radley becomes the mysterious interest of neighborhood kids. Boo Radley is never seen or heard, coming or going and so whispers and gossips abound. All the dark epithets hurl his way. If chosen, this county in the South would elect Boo Radley as the perfect candidate for the title of modern day creep. Yet despite it all, Boo exchanges gifts and kindness and even stands up for the children on his block, be it life or death. So while courtrooms decide on continued hate, towns carry on in their ignorance, a southern people their myopia, a nameless recluse from nowhere teaches "love thy neighbor" principles.

The trained human weapon used for espionage, intelligence, re-con, combat, and nothing else. Since childhood, Black Widow fought her way across continents and allegiances. Just where the law stops, vengeance and justice begins, Natasha doesn't know. She doesn't even remember being abducted as a child, if she was really to excel as a ballerina in a different life. But for now, she fights on against the villains of the world, joining an assembly of other heroes. Acrobatic in moves, astute in martial arts, keen in spy tactics, Black Widow makes peace with her situation and her nature. The past would be a villain she beats alongside the present, the real hero.

America and the world's lovable loser, Charlie Brown is the iconic archetype of the average kid. He leads his Peanuts gang in their everyday antics: the highs and lows of kid play. But Charlie is not the hero of stardom; he carries no badge of distinction or plaques for the wall, trophies for the mantle. He just carries rejections, frustrations, defeats, and so carries the hearts of millions just like him: naive, cynical, hapless sometimes, excited other times. We quietly root for this underdog. We want him to win the feat, beat the odds, stand tall and mighty before the crowds - just once. But we know Life dealt him and us a different hand and he never wins. But finally, a little guy got his face in the newspaper.

The singer gives us the enduring chorus of modern times. Echoing the confusion and unassuaged numbness through the years and places, roads and fields, the singer reminds us all of our own hungers, yearnings, lost loves and lost days, our emptiness. He reminisces of bygone childhood moments in the carefree long ago, chasing horizons. But now the landscapes have changed. The routine of adulthood sets in. Our stifled souls don't know how to express the void. But the singer still looks to friends and love's smile to pull him through with hope beyond hope to survive the distances and times. Yes, he shows us that even a glass half empty can still quench a soul's thirst.
Quote: Looking out at the road rushing under my wheels/ Looking back at the years gone by like so many summer fields/ In sixty-five I was seventeen and running up one-oh-one/ I don't know where I'm running now, I'm just running on/ Running on, running on empty/ Running on, running blind/ Running on, running into the sun/ But I'm running behind/ Gotta do what you can just to keep your love alive/ Trying not to confuse it with what you do to survive/ In sixty-nine I was twenty-one and I called the road my own/ I don't know when that road turned, into the road I'm on/...Looking out at the road rushing under my wheels/ I don't know how to tell you all just how crazy this life feels Look around for the friends that I used to turn to to pull me through/ Looking into their eyes I see them running too

Description: The quintessence of the average GI Joe, the freckled, hapless, goof-off, perpetual shirker, Beetle Bailey makes his way through the drills and regiment and structure of an army training camp. Always bombarded by authority heads and insane rules, Beetle survives somehow. We little guys caught in our own mundane routine can see a little bit of ourselves in Beetle Bailey. We too want a break from bureaucracy and procedures. We too want simplicity in a chaotic world. We too joke in quiet hours with our rag tag friends. So Beetle is a refreshing mirror to our everyday selves and gladly we will march alongside and fight with him in that larger camp called Life.

A sweet, aching voice penetrating the darkness, the singer finds healing in love-making. When the blue teardrops fall, when the waves rise and rise, when emotional stability fades, he finds a balm in Gilead with intimacy. For so long intercourse carried every connotation, good or bad, but hardly one of healing for all the shivering, lonely souls out there. No more the stormy skies, sick mornings with a loved one a phone call away. Our singer in soulful eloquence paints the magic of two humans exchanging in a natural human moment, the love-spirit in the flesh. The music that can heal any who ever claimed in the end: "cause I'm all alone".

Character: Singer, I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For
Description: Echoing from highest heights to soul's depths, the singer's voice embodies all the surreal yearning, wonder, ache, and hope that can be contained in the human vessel. With spiritual searching, the singer moves between the continuum of angels and devils. He tried and tried up mountains, through the fields, up city walls, through the night and is still running. What does he look for in painstaking earnestness? It can only be a thing with no name: a peace, solace, absolution, salvation, love ever after, kingdom to come. And as we yield and submit to the cosmos, our own unsuccessful searching mirrors much like the singer's who still roams the night when others sleep looking for the unknown, unnamed substance not found on Earth.
Quote: I believe in the Kingdom come/ Then all the colors will bleed into one/ Bleed into one/ But yes, I'm still running/ You broke the bonds/ and you loosened chains/ carried the cross of my shame, of my shame/ You know I believe it/ But I still haven't found/ What I'm looking for

Description: The grieving, turmoiled spirit caught up in a thug's life and hoping to follow God 24/7. But the everyday crimes tear away at the singer. He is pushed and pulled, yanked and dragged back and forth in his moral compass. His environment, his family, and friends, the violence all around, his life's chances forces the singer on an ill-fated destiny. And deep down his faith keeps him going. And he knows in the hereafter there is no mercy for him and his kind. He survived the jungle to be doomed for eternity with tears of pain in between. And still he questions and broods for the answer beyond the reason of his grief. And the only reply he can hear back is: "we live to die."
Quote: Follow the Lord all 24/7 days/ God is who we praise/ Even though the Devil's all up in my face/ But He keepin' me safe and in my place/ Say grace to the gates we race/ Without a chance to face the judge/ Then I guess my soul won't budge/ Grudge, because there's no mercy for thugs/ Ooh, what could I do?/ It's all about a family and how we roll/ Can I get a witness? Let it unfold/ We livin' our lives to eternal our souls...Livin' in a hateful world/ Sendin' me (straight to Heaven)/ That's how we roll/ And I asked the good Lord why/ And inside, he told me we live to die

Character: Speaker, I'm Nobody! Who are You?
Description: The perky little voice who doesn't mind being forgotten, nameless, infinitesimal. The speaker invites us to relish one's unnamed self who never sees the limelight, the spotlight, the newspaper headlines, the viral video. Happily relinquishing the worthless things of this world, the speaker is a reassuring and refreshing voice. Where everyone runs for the stampede of fame and fortune, status and inner circles, the speaker stands by the wayside reaching out a hand to the left-behinds and left-outs. She even amuses us on the worthless things of this world called a human name with no more currency than mud or a bog. She begs us to keep the title of Nobody as if the meek who inherit the world will do so quietly, unpublished.
Quote: I'm Nobody! Who are you?/ Are you – Nobody – too?/ Then there's a pair of us!/ Don't tell! they'd advertise – you know!/ How dreary – to be – Somebody!/ How public – like a Frog –  / To tell one's name – the livelong June – / To an admiring Bog!

Description: The pleading voice who asks no more but to be remembered by name, to hold a hand in heaven. Accompanied by the rhythmic plucking of guitar strings, the singer's sad, gentle, weary crooning shakes the fiber of any conscious being. He is ever so restless, believing heaven is not for him. And that he must continue onward night and day for his true belonging, for the peace everlasting where there is no pain or tears. He rightfully affirms the gravity hard truth of earthly life that time can break you down. Can we squeeze the singer's shoulders? Can we stop his restless soul from wandering? Can we tell him if he would believe us that it is only him and his kind who ever belonged in heaven?
Quote: Would you know my name/ If I saw you in heaven?/ Would it be the same/ If I saw you in heaven?/ I must be strong and carry on/ 'Cause I know I don't belong here in heaven/ Would you hold my hand/ If I saw you in heaven?/ Would you help me stand/ If I saw you in heaven?/ I'll find my way through night and day/ 'Cause I know I just can't stay here in heaven

Description: Heartbreak's living incarnate voice, the singer carries the heaviness and pain of a lost modern day romance. As he talks to the telephone operator for a little contact number to prove his bravado and muster against an estranged beau and friend we feel his pain reverberate with plucked guitar strings. And it hurts all the more with the real thing -a love that would save the singer. We all were in his shoes once who saw our loved one steal off into the sunset. We fought back the tears. We denied or minimized the true effect. We tried the words to beat how we feel. The singer unites us all with our shared pain. He even becomes our hero to calmly surrender the need to prove himself to his ex-lover and does so in music.

The exasperated voice who sees his infinitesimal self in the broader, larger scope of cities and universe. Defeated, he sees the crowds, the trains, cities, and debases himself lower among the multitude. What does it all mean? What do I do now? Where shall I go? These are the silent questions asked but never answered. And then he sees the years recurring before and after and all the waste and wear of the human soul: lost days, unachieved goals, vain body of work, the aching mind. And then he hears a voice, learns a lesson of enough, of being small in an enormous existence -that to leave a crumb, a trace, a verse is still worthwhile.
Quote: Oh me! Oh life! of the questions of these recurring,/ Of the endless trains of the faithless, of cities fill'd with the foolish,/ Of myself forever reproaching myself, (for who more foolish than I, and who more faithless?)/ Of eyes that vainly crave the light, of the objects mean, of the struggle ever renew'd,/ Of the poor results of all, of the plodding and sordid crowds I see around me, Of the empty and useless years of the rest, with the rest me intertwined,/ The question, O me! so sad, recurring—What good amid these, O me, O life?

Description: A tenacious, ever hopeful, ever persistent boy who kept on believing with no encouraging proof. Even when everyone near and dear told him a simple carrot seed will not come up the boy who listened intently to every word still believed otherwise. And didn't just sit and wait but worked. He pulled, tended, watered that plant. If ever there was a living testimony to human perseverance this is the story. We know it is not just a carrot seed but all the hard-earned, striving goals, tangible and intangible, of this world and the next. And this isn't just any boy but a symbol of the best in the human spirit. Our boy is a hero who beat the naysayers with patience and resolve who hoped beyond hope and hard enough to create a miracle.

Heavy-hearted, broken-spirited the anguished speaker finds himself walking the burial grounds. He comes to see the inevitable end of all humans, the threshold crossed and never returned. He learns the transience of it all, the vanity of all works and acts. And through this catharsis, studying the abyss, his pride shatters. With such revelation what worth can there be to hold grudges, that our visit on earth is too short for pointless trifles where wronged and wrongdoer end in the same fate. Yes, the speaker broke his pride and forgave, finding it better to sink in the grave with brotherly, neighborly spirit than burdened with pointless petty earthly cares.
Quote: Where, pondering how all human love and hate/ Find one sad level; and how, soon or late,/ Wronged and wrongdoer, each with meekened face,/ And cold hands folded over a still heart,/ Pass the green threshold of our common grave,/ Whither all footsteps tend, whence none depart,/ Awed for myself, and pitying my race,/ Our common sorrow, like a mighty wave,/ Swept all my pride away, and trembling I forgave!

Description: Entranced by a bird's singing but anguished in state of mind, the speaker vacillates between reality and revelry. He uses the nightingale as a symbol of a better world, far past and beyond the death and pain in purity and song. He even wishes to flee with the nightingale away from the race of men in the very essence of Poetry. So long has he brooded and romanticized Death itself. Rising and falling, ebbing and flowing in wonderment, anticipation, weariness and longing, the speaker pours onto the bird a soulful introspection. But reality kicks in and the dream ends. But it seems a part of the speaker may have flown away.
Quote: Fade far away, dissolve, and quite forget/ What thou among the leaves hast never known,/ The weariness, the fever, and the fret/ Here, where men sit and hear each other groan;/ Where palsy shakes a few, sad, last gray hairs,/ Where youth grows pale, and spectre-thin, and dies;/ Where but to think is to be full of sorrow/ And leaden-eyed despairs,/ Where Beauty cannot keep her lustrous eyes,/ Or new Love pine at them beyond to-morrow.

Description: Completely destitute of all things, the speaker pours out a dirge to the world. Everyone around filled with purpose, life, bounty, busy enjoying life, the speaker finds himself naked in atomic nullity with no place to go, nothing to do, no one for him. Stripped of all worldly things he thinks of himself as a newborn -mute, dumb, empty- and the pain of such emptiness transmutes to confusion, frustration, restlessness. He drifts on nowhere like the waves and wind. All in stark contrast to everyone else he seems to be dying in the lost days and time. But the anguished speaker learns a valuable lesson that in his emptiness he nourishes on something of the soul, gaining true enlightenment.
Quote: Other people are contented, enjoying the sacrificial feast of the ox./ In spring some go to the park, and climb the terrace,/ But I alone am drifting not knowing where I am./ Like a new-born babe before it learns to smile,/ I am alone, without a place to go./ ...Oh, I drift like the waves of the sea./ Without direction, like the restless wind./ Everyone else is busy,/ But I alone am aimless and depressed./ I am different./ I am nourished by the great mother.

Description: Onward toward an uncertain journey, the speaker absorbs all the everyday beauties around him -above, below, here and there. Yet sadly no one shares in his momentous wonder of flower and sun. As he stands still all around are people coming and going, no one staying, no one stopping or glancing back: no smile, no song, no look of eye, no human exchange. And later he rests at the scorn of his acquaintances who too do not care for the passing scene and moment. The speaker is a tender, sensitive creature embracing the delicious presence, here and now. He even finds that the journey is neither hard nor long when you walk in the spirit of all things, destined for a human rendezvous.
Quote: the wealth of gold was scattered through the rift of the clouds while we busily went on our way and paid no heed. We sang no glad songs nor played; we went not to the village for barter; we spoke not a word nor smiled; we lingered not on the way. We quickened our pace more and more as the time sped by.

Description: The tortured urban Mid-Westerner who pounded out the anguish of his soul in rap battles. From impoverished settings and meager origins and dismal odds, Jimmy B-Rabbit never had a chance. He fights to keep afloat with blue-collared work. He fights to overcome his trailer park, rundown roots. He fights to command respect among his peers. He fights and fights. And so long running away from his problems and weaknesses, Jimmy eventually embraces them and turns it into ironic puns and beat box punchlines. And if ever a bullying word smith comes to ridicule the poor, the weak, the outcasts, bet your last dollar Jimmy B-Rabbit will be on the scene to fight back and duel the bully until the last Mic drops.

Character: Singer, My Love is Your Love
Description: Singing a love song about the Judgment Day, homelessness, World War III, aging, even death, the singer captures the essence of unconditional love. She paints a love with no ego, no status, no wealth or assets, no success or ambition, just wholly human connection that even the afterlife cannot tear apart. Her lullaby, melodic, tranquil voice carries an accepting understanding as if she seen it all -the mystery of the cosmos, the eventuality of all things, the very face of God. And she finds only love matters -the kind that sleeps on the street and train station with you, ages with you, through all peril and destruction. And living in such moments and spirit is a life well-spent.
Quote: If tomorrow is judgement day (sing mommy)/ And I'm standin' on the front line/ And the Lord ask me what I did with my life/ I will say I spent it with you/ If I wake up in World War 3/ I see destruction and poverty/ And I feel like I want to go home/ It's okay if you're comin' with me/… If I lose my fame and fortune/ And I'm homeless on the street/ And I'm sleepin' in Grand Central Station/ It's okay if you're sleepin' with me/ As the years they pass us by/We stay young through each other's eyes/ And no matter how old we get/ It's okay as long as I got you babe

Description: The youngest, last and least daughter cast out among her other sisters in beauty and grace, Sephora is a simple shepherd girl who keeps a gentle, faithful soul in a quiet desert corner of the world. And when compared to woman's beauty, indulgences, and conveniences, Sephora reminds us of the inner beauty: quiet as the green valleys and still waters. Sephora even reminds us of the true, pure love and faith of strong willed people with good values. With her sincere, beautiful spirit by a crusader's side, little wonder miracles triumph and shepherds surmount the power of pharaohs. Any flash and dash, glitter and glow, anything popular and vain, pale to the Sephoras of the old and new world.
Quote: A jewel has brilliant fire, but it gives no warmth. Our hands are not so soft, but they can serve. Our bodies not so white, but they are strong. Our lips are not perfumed, but they speak the truth. Love is not an art to us. It's life to us. We are not dressed in gold and fine linen. Strength and honor are our clothing. Our tents are not the columned halls of Egypt, but our children play happily before them. We can offer you little... but we offer all we have.
